key_insight: Uniform-attention and trainable-attention architectures that previously appeared to implement different modular-addition circuits actually realize the same algorithm: their internal representations are topologically and geometrically equivalent manifolds.
problem_solved: Clarifies whether architectural differences (uniform vs. learnable attention) produce distinct algorithms for modular addition, resolving interpretability ambiguity about circuit-level differences by proving representational equivalence.
method: Compare representation manifolds from both architectures using geometric and topological analyses (e.g., low-dimensional embeddings, manifold alignment, and topological invariants).
Demonstrate mappings between manifolds that preserve the computation (showing homeomorphism/diffeomorphism-like equivalence) and validate with empirical measurements across models.
Use visualization and quantitative metrics to show that apparent circuit differences (Clock vs. Pizza) are reparameterizations of the same underlying algorithm.
impact: Reconciles conflicting interpretability narratives and shows that distinct architectural designs can implement the same algorithmic solution, informing model design, debugging, and trustworthiness analyses.
visual_elements: Side-by-side manifold embeddings (e.g., PCA/UMAP) of internal representations for both architectures with mapped correspondences highlighted.
Schematic circuit diagrams (Clock vs. Pizza) annotated to show the reparameterization/mapping that makes them equivalent.
Topological summary (persistence diagrams or barcodes) demonstrating matched invariants between models.
Heatmap or alignment matrix showing one-to-one mapping / transformation between representation coordinates.
paper_title: On the geometry and topology of representations: the manifolds of modular addition
